title: How did the Mongols treat cities that surrendered without a fight? - Quora

response.answer_text: Generally speaking, the official policy of the Mongols under Genghis and his successors was that any city that submitted without resistance would be treated fairly, allowed even to keep some of the local leadership in place (provided they swore fealty to the Mongols) and have their local laws and customs respected. They also often got Mongol military protection against other enemies. However, at least some degree of looting and pillaging still often happened, depending on the local Mongol commander and the discipline of his troops. Being allowed to loot/pillage/rape was one of the “perks” of victory for ancient armies (in a sense it was part of how soldiers were “paid”, and the more they had to fight and bleed for the victory, the more they expected to be allowed to do so). So even if there was an order from above or standing policy to spare a city, the local troops on sight may not always obey it to the letter. In most cases this was still better for the city in question than total destruction. If your city was part of a larger political entity that had really pissed the Mongols off, and they had decided to make an example of your entire nation, however, you were usually hooped no matter what you did. On rare occasions, a city that resisted well enough actually impressed the Mongols enough that they would offer not only mercy for the city, but for at least part of that city’s army to join the Mongol army itself, though very few opponents of the Mongols in their heydey were able to resist that well.

The Mongols took these cities and states as allies. They were defending their allies. For example Alexander Nevsky. Nevsky proved to be a cautious and far-sighted politician. He dismissed the Roman Curia’s attempts to cause war between Russia and the Golden Horde, because he understood the uselessness of such war with the Tatars at a time when they were still a powerful force. Historians seem to be unsure about Alexander’s behavior when it came to his relations with Mongols. He may have thought that Catholicism presented a more tangible threat to Russian national identity than paying a tribute to the Khan, who had little interest in Russian religion and culture. It is also argued that he intentionally kept Russia as a vassal to the Mongols in order to preserve his own status and counted on the befriended Horde in case someone challenged his authority (he forced the citizens of Novgorod to pay tribute). Nevsky tried to strengthen his authority at the expense of the boyars and at the same time suppress any anti-Mongol and anti-Muscovite uprisings in the country (Novgorod Uprising of 1259).

In one city in the middle east they offered to leave the place intact and not kill anyone if they simply opened the gates, and the king handed over the contents of the treasury. When he refused they laid siege, eventually took the city, and made the king drink some of his own gold. Obviously after heating it up a little.Another story I read they were so impressed with the city's archers that after they took the city they made all the archers breed with their own camp follower women, then they chopped off the right hand of the archers.

I’m sure the terms varied from city to city and Mongol leader to Mongol leader, but — in at least a few documented cases in Eastern Europe — the Mongols offered terms as reasonable as “give us 10% of your stuff, pledge your allegiance to the Great Khan and we’ll be on our way” The sooner they could check off another victory, expand the empire and send a caravan of loot back to the home folk, the better. A long siege was a painful irritation and they’d make sure you regretted closing those gates. They’d also make sure the next walled city down the road heard how it went down and understood this was the wrong choice.

I remember reading something that if the Mongols chose to raid your city, it was better to open your gates and let them in. They’d kill the leaders of the city and maybe a few unlucky others but that is much easier to deal with than losing the entire city population in an attempt to fight them off. Kind of ruins the point of walls back then, doesn’t it? That’s how scary the Mongols were.

it depended on the whim of the commander in charge of the horde at your door. there were reported cases of even when cities surrendered their populace being butchered and the town burned. think about it. once you open your home to criminals why would they be content to only take 10% of your stuff when they could take it all? rape only 10% of the women when they could rape them all? dead folks tell no tales. who’s gonna know or report it if the Mongols take a city that surrendered and kill everyone and take all the stuff?
